title: 111_hr5154
content: The Act may be cited as the "Public Housing Energy Savings Act of 2010" and focuses on utility and waste management cost savings. The Public Housing Energy Savings Act of 2010 amends section 9(e)(2)(C) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 to ensure public housing agencies benefit from cost savings in utilities and waste management due to energy conservation improvements. The Public Housing Energy Savings Act of 2010 amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to benefit public housing agencies from cost savings in utilities and waste management through energy conservation improvements. The act includes provisions for energy conservation improvements in public housing projects, with specific guidelines for third-party contracts and effective dates. The Public Housing Energy Savings Act of 2010 allows public housing agencies to finance energy conservation improvements for up to 20 years. Operating assistance can be used as security for such financing. The Secretary may establish the amount of utility cost savings from improvements and permit the pledging of installed equipment. Public housing agencies can elect to be paid for utility costs under a formula for up to 20 years. The Secretary may adjust utility cost savings for public housing agencies based on their average annual consumption over a 3-year period. Initial adjustments account for differences in heating degree day averages over a 20-year period. The Secretary may adjust utility cost savings for public housing agencies based on their average annual consumption over a 3-year period, making ongoing adjustments in the consumption base level for various reasons. The housing agency can choose to use third-party services for its energy conservation program but is not obligated to do so. The agency has full discretion over the source, terms, and conditions of any financing used for the program.
